text: I say this because i dont feel we are ignoring human suffering. I think that there is just so much human suffering that we need to pick and choose where to divert our attention to. In addition to that, i think the media has sort of desensitized human suffering since it is so common. For this reason, we as humans have more of a emotional reaction when we see animals being taken advantage of over humans. We understand that both are wrong, however we see it so often for humans that we sort of just repress it in a way. I think that emotional reaction is still there if we see a kid being harmed, however a grown adult we just sort of brush aside. As far as the 40 percent saving their dog over a tourist, i think i would have to agree. Our dog is like family, so if there was a life to save i would probably go with my dog. I would not really be super sad if something happened to the tourist, simply because i do not know them personally. If something happened to my dog i would be extremely upset and saddened. Its an easy choice for me, but i would just relate it to family over non family. So being more empathetic to suffering animals is really just something that society has done to us in a way i guess. It would be interesting to find out how humans would react to stimuli involing a human death and animal death, if they had grown up in an era with no media aside from writing. Maybe the reaction would be higher for humans because they can relate to a human death more. I dont find it wrong either way to focus on welfare of animals or humans, because if that is what your focused on that you are an empathetic individual. Everyone's perspective is different and what may cause one person to take the death of a human strongly, may not do the same to someone else. This is the beauty in everyone being different, and having had different experiences. Just from my own perspective, i think i would probably have the stronger reaction seeing a dog being beat by a bat over an adult. But if it was a child instead i think the child would take the cake over an animal, but thats just me. Anyway, in conclusion, i dont think it is wrong to focus on animal welfare at all, i think everyone is different and people are going to focus on what makes them most enthusiastic.

If you don't know where your country stands on the world stage, how can you intelligently weigh in on the validity of candidates' foreign policy claims? It's not a responsibility though. Anything that is extremely important will be told through the grapevine anyway. Staying up to date with current events can help people but I don't think it's bad if you don't stay up to date. This goes on a local, state and federal level. I don't see how knowing about a murder in New York City is going to affect me when I live on Long Island. All that news is going to do for me personally is make me sad. I don't want to hear about murder. I don't want to hear about people dying, getting robbed and all things like that. It instantly will take me from a good mood to a bad one. I only want to be surrounded with positive information. I know that's impossible but just avoiding the news does help big time in that regard. We aren't bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news. Possibly ignorant to many things that are happening around us but sometimes ignorance is a very good thing. Sometimes not knowing something allows it to not have a negative affect on you at all. I keep up with the news on social media because if a story is big enough, I'll see it on my timeline. That's the way that I like to see my news, and that's the way it's going to stay.

text: Technology allows us to communicate with our significant other no matter where we are in the world. Inventions such as FaceTime allow for long distance relationships to not feel so distant. These apps help take the stress and anxiety away from meeting someone for the first time. You can ease into a 'relationship' by talking online with someone first. This allows you to get to know someone and get information on whether you are most likely compatible with them or not. Technology has personally helped me when it comes to dating. I have used Tinder a couple of times and actually found my current girlfriend on there. I feel like it's a very easy way to break the ice and let someone know that you're interested in them. All you have to do is swipe right and they know you're at least interesting in speaking to them. To me, technology takes a lot of the nerves away from dating. I have been on first dates before where I was very nervous and a lot of that is because I didn't really know the other person. I was going to have to do everything in person which can be a bit hard. text: Humans are capable of reasoning and rationalizing, as well as making decisions. They understand the things that are causing their suffering, and they are capable of changing their lives, actions, or environments in order to alleviate it. Animals, on the other hand, cannot mediate their suffering in this way. A suffering human can often escape the forces causing their pain, while a suffering animal stays in its environment and is incapable of finding relief, unless chance or death, or a concerned human, intervenes to bring them relief. We also tend to view humans as responsible for their own suffering, while animals are seen as non-volitional, innocent, and deserving of sympathy. In other words, a suffering human is often viewed as 'getting what they deserve', while a miserable animal is seen as pitiful and undeserving of their suffering.
label: user_and_api

text: To a certain extent, these things are true. Humans are different than animals, and have much greater capacity to reason and make decisions, and can often escape their circumstances, while animals cannot. To this extent, it is somewhat reasonable to conclude that we have a greater responsibility to animals than to humans, especially when the human whose welfare is at stake has a presumed obligation to see to their own preservation.
label: user_and_api

text: In this sense, we are the shepherds of animals, while other humans are assumed to be their own shepherds. So while the tendency is understandable, it overlooks certain things. Humans are animals, too, with greater capabilities than most, but still, subject to many of the same forces of nature as any other animal, and similar limits when it comes to their ability to change these circumstances. While it might be comforting to assume that humans can do something about the obstacles that they face, it is often the case that small, seemingly petty factors can combine to force humans into a corner that they cannot get out of. So, those who reserve their sympathy for animals might be well-advised to reconsider their priorities when it comes to the suffering of an individual, helpless human. Because if a helpless animal is deserving of pity, and help, a helpless human, who is ultimately just another suffering animal,  is deserving of this, as well. It makes no sense to respond to the suffering of one animal, and ignore the suffering of another who is equally, if not more, worthy of empathy and help.

text: The reason I believe this, is that existing sports already contain some inherently dangerous components, most of which result in serious injury on a fairly frequent basis, and some of which can even result in death. For example, football players experience bodily collisions with other players to the point of severe bodily damage on a regular basis. Broken bones and torn ligaments are almost routine, and concussions are common. A fair amount of football players --particularly in the high school and college ranks--suffer from post-concussion syndrome (which may not present itself for several months after the injury), and can effect them for the rest of their lives, and several players have suffered neck injuries that have resulted in permanent paralysis. Boxing, of course, is another sport that has a decidedly high risk of injury and death, as does MMA, while even sports that don't involve hard impacts with other players, like baseball and tennis, have their own unusual dangers, such as flying balls and obstacles that result in serious injury, and track competitors risk sprains or broken limbs from hurdles, high jumps and the long jump. Even golfers , whose sport is considered relatively safe in the grand scheme of things, can suffer minor injuries like chronic arthritis from repetitive motion, and serious injuries and even death by lightning strikes. My point is, that the risks of engaging in sports, are already high, and are inherent, and expected. Perhaps sports that mean certain death should be banned, but barring that, I can't see preventing competition in extreme sports, because if that were to occur, many just as dangerous (or even more so) existing sports would need to be banned as well,  which would lead to very few sports in which an athlete could lawfully compete.

text: It is not good for our health, our relationships, or our ability to connect with the world around us. In terms of health, staring at a screen can cause eye strain, dry eyes, headaches and neck pain. Though people might attempt 'online exercise programs', screen time in general leads to more sedentary behavior, and therefore to weight gain and obesity. It also creates trends in behavior that might carry on into the future, when the virus is no longer a concern, so these negative impacts on healthy behavior could be long-lasting. When it comes to relationships, looking at other people via a screen is not the same as interacting with  them in person. Particularly when it comes to children, there is a lot of research showing that the more time they spend on screens, the less time they spend interacting with their parents and siblings. Certain social and behavioral cues can't be conveyed on a screen; the same is true of the non-verbal cues that are so important to communication. While the impact on adults might be relatively minor, all this screen time is causing a generation of children to miss out on the important developmental benefits of face-to-face interaction. In terms of general connection with the world around us, screen time is causing us to miss out on real things, occurring in our neighborhoods and communities, and focus on arbitrary things, occurring only on the internet.
label: user_and_api

text: or on the other side of the world. In this way, screen time is causing us to lose a proper sense of place and connection with the world around us, and by that, I mean the portions of the world that should be important and meaningful to us. Instead we're ending up with stronger connections to people we will never meet, places we will never visit, and things that don't really affect us. The fact is, the dramatic increase in relying on computers and the internet to get by, was meant to be a temporary solution to a short-term problem. It was never meant to be a permanent solution to a long-term problem, and if we treat it that way, we may find that the problems it causes, are far worse than anything caused by a novel flu virus.

text: For starters, audiobooks are useful when driving, strolling in the park, cooking, cleaning, or doing any other activity that requires you to be able to see what you 're doing rather than focusing on a a book. Books offer no corresponding advantage, as the main activity that audiobooks might prevent, listening to music or other audio, is something that would also prevent the level of focus required to read a book. That brings up another advantage of audiobooks, the fact that they not only free up our eyes, but don't require the same level of focus that reading does. It's possible to attempt to read a book, and end up unable to follow what's going on and getting distracted and losing your place, while with an audiobook, you might well be able to make your way through the recording without getting distracted, and still retain what's going on in the story. Audiobooks also better engage the imagination. The sound of the words being read aloud, is immeasurably more evocative than their appearance on a page, and it's also the case that, when using sound rather than sight to engage our mental processes, we tend to engage them more fully, using both sides of our brain to process the resulting data, rather than just the one side that reading hard copy books activates. There's also the fact that audiobook narrators are often good enough that they can add an extra dimension to the story, or just their reading voice in itself is worth listening to, which can not only elevate a decent story, but also enhance the experience of reading something that's otherwise uninteresting by itself. Audiobooks are also accessible in areas where books may not be available. Not everyone has a tablet, and many people attempting to read e-books on public transit or on trains experience difficulties like motion sickness, while doing so, either due to the glare on their screen or just the general inconvenience of reading while moving.
label: user_and_api

text: Also, audiobooks enable us to tune out distractions while listening to them on headphones in public settings like mass transit, whereas books lack the ability to do that. In closing, audiobooks are in no regard worse than books, and in many ways, better. If I were forced to choose one over the other, I'd have to say that, for me, as well as most people, the myriad extra benefits of listening to audiobooks would more than compensate for any loss that the lack of a printed page could entail.

text: I think these are the two most important things that students should learn while in school. This is because time management and communication are invaluable skills to have in any setting, regardless of whether the student goes on to work in a professional industry or not. Even a person who doesn't have a 'traditional' job, such as a stay at home mom, can benefit from being able to manage her time efficiently and communicate well with others. I currently have a job working as a restaurant hostess. Certainly I don't have the 'best' job, and I'm sure many people don't consider it a 'real' job, but I'm sure you would be surprised at how much my efficiency, or lack thereof, can help or hurt my restaurant. If I'm not managing my time well, it can mess up other servers' tables. And I'm sure you would also be surprised at how my communication skills can make or break my job. For example, if a customer asks me a question, and I don't answer them quickly, it can make the customer angry. As another example, if I answer the phone in a cheerful manner, it makes the customer happy. So really, even though I don't have a traditional job in an office setting, it's still really useful to know how to effectively communicate and manage my time. These should really be the pillars of what students should learn in school. Yes, it's of course important to learn math or science or history, but I truly believe that knowing how to effectively communicate and manage your time is almost infinitely more useful than anything else you might be learning from your teachers. After all, I hardly ever have to use geometry or algebra in my day-to-day life, but if I'm the hostess at a restaurant and a table of customers is upset about something, it's up to me to manage my other tasks so I can get to their table quickly, apologize and make them happy. I can definitely count on one hand the number of times I've had to make change with scientific notation in my current job, but I know how to communicate clearly with customers. And I think that's why my boss has me as the hostess, not another person with many more years of experience. My boss has always said that it's important to have a person who can interact with people well as the front person of the restaurant. And that's why he chose to have me do this for him, because even though it's only been a year, I've already shown that I am capable of effectively interacting with his most valued patrons. In conclusion, effective communication and time management have really allowed me to excel in my current situation, and I believe they would also be extremely valuable to success in any career. If I ever change careers in the future, I am certain that I will be well equipped for success because of what I currently know. For these reasons, I am confident that the most important things students should learn in school are how to effectively manage their time and communicate clearly. After all, do students really need to know about polar explorers when they could be learning how to effectively handle their lives in the real world? I don't even know what polar explorers are, but I sure am a good hostess! And does knowing what polar explorers are pay my rent or help me afford a car?

Is it possible for a work to be so well written that I can overlook the offensive portrayal? I find it hard to believe that I could ever do that, but I suppose it's possible. I think the problem is that I would have to be so caught up in the story that I wouldn't constantly notice the offensive portrayal. text: For this reason, I would generally prefer not to watch or read something that revels in stereotypes, but sometimes I endure such things because of the cultural or entertainment value. I suspect that if I was a member of a marginalized group, or was otherwise directly affected, I might take a stronger stance against such works. text: Please note that in all cases, I am not claiming negligence on the part of the author.

text: I cannot know or predict what the author truly had in mind, but I will allow for the possibility (nay, the probability) that the author was simply relaying feelings that he or she had picked up from society. The fact that society felt this way is not the author's fault, but I still take exception to the fact that the author reinforces these feelings. So, onto the business at hand, the most common and harmful stereotype I see is that of black people. This goes back to the Jim Crow era in which African-Americans were portrayed as happy fools who loved to work on plantations, where they could dance and sing in the sunlight. Needless to say, this was never true, but it made white audiences feel better about themselves. In this one case, I think that the stereotype was indeed created from willful malice. Hattie McDaniels's character in Gone with the Wind is another example. She is portrayed as someone who would be helpless if she was not enslaved by a rich white family, and we are meant to believe that she is grateful for what she received. However, this is also an instance in which a black woman was humanized and portrayed fairly respectfully on screen, so I cannot totally object to it. For a far more serious example, let us consider the trope of the 'black friend.'
label: api

text: This is often a character who is portrayed with no depth, and simply exists to make the main characters (who are almost always white) appear to be more tolerant and worldly. A black friend simply exists to make the audience think that the white characters are more popular and universally appreciated. At times, the black friend even ends up having some connection to the underworld, which the main characters can harmlessly exploit. This is just as bad as explicitly claiming that all black people are involved in crime, because that is what the audience is led to believe. This might actually be beneficial for society, because audiences who came to see a heroic white cast, might end up learning a subtle lesson about questioning the stereotypes that pervade our society. Unfortunately, I cannot readily think of an example in which I have seen this happen in fiction, and there have been far to many examples of harmful stereotypes. I hope that the few examples which I had time to share were illustrative of the broader point.

text: Since the dawn of time, people have managed to establish intimate relationships by meeting each other in real life, gradually learning to trust one another, and eventually being at the point to where they really want to begin a relationship with each other. 21st century technological developments have only added a layer of bizarre complexity to this process, and have further isolated people to the point where this process fails before it can even begin. Dating apps are the greatest example of this. I've used them, and the experience is not unlike playing online poker, or playing video games -- the main point of it is to kill time in lieu of having better things to do. The way the time killing process works with them, is that, you open up the app, conveniently right around the time you would otherwise go to bed, and start swiping through dozens of unappealing or phony users until you find one or two that you like, and begin exchanging messages with them, which might then end in a flaky or disconnected face-to-face interaction, which might then end in a crappy date that doesn't lead to anything further, which then leads you back to the beginning with yet more profiles of people you don't have anything in common with, and who you don't really want to meet. This does nothing to build a foundation of trust and rapport, and it does nothing to help people connect with each other. Netflix is a mere time waster, it's much like going to a video store, only with thousands of titles rather than hundreds, few of which either you or a prospective partner will have any interest in watching, and the whole process is more likely to result in awkward silence and resentment over poor viewing choices, than a romantic connection. Texting is very much the same way -- the only difference is that it sucks even more time out of your day, and takes more from your life, as you fail over and over to communicate with someone like a real human being, and wind up resorting to emoticons.
label: user_and_api

text: What all of these things have in common, beyond being ineffectual for dating or relationships, is that they are all means for some greedy corporate entity to make money, and ultimately if you build a real relationship, the money making will stop, so they have interest in facilitating relationships. The best response is to ignore them all, and meet someone in the gym, library, a book store, coffee shop, or on a hiking trail somewhere. Then, once you're in a relationship, you can rest satisfied, knowing that not only have you met someone you might spend the rest of your life with, you've also saved a ton of money in the process and helped to put Netflix out of business.

text: Most of what I think of as extreme sports are a contest in which an individual pushes his or her own personal limits. text: Fiction is intrinsically based on stereotypes and generalizations about people or situations, because it is a way of condensing life into some kind of literary, visual, or auditory shorthand that is much easier to consume for the reader. Stereotypes are very much a part of this, because creating an archetype or an archetype package for a character is a quick way for readers to be able to define that character in their mind as a character representing a certain group or circumstances. Without stereotypes, fiction can be very difficult to write, and too long-winded for readers to bother with. Of course, this doesn't mean that using stereotypes is entirely acceptable. Some stereotypes, such as dated racial or cultural ones , have grown so outdated through changing times that they're now universally viewed as offensive. Examples of this are black characters once considered benign, and cheerful, like Stepin Fetchit, Aunt Jemima or Uncle Remus, who are now considered offensive racial stereotypes no one in their right mind would create. Similar ones include characters once seen as heroic, like Tonto and the Lone Ranger, who are now seen as bigoted and politically incorrect.
label: user_and_api

text: This isn't because stereotyping in fiction is bad, though. It's simply because of the way history, cultures and values change over time.
label: user_and_api

text: Many of today's stories, though they bend over backwards to be 'politically correct' and 'non-problematic' have stereotypes. The 'bad father', the 'overworked single mother', the 'depressed woman with a cat', the 'female character who is more capable, smarter, and morally virtuous than any of the male characters' are all examples of modern stereotypes that are acceptable now, but will one day doubtless be viewed as offensive, dated, and in bad taste, to the same extent Uncle Remus is now. So I personally, accept stereotypes in fiction, and would never turn down or run from a book or a film because of its presence.
label: user_and_api

text: I try to see beyond the stereotype. to the universal story that the writer is attempting to tell, and encourage other readers and viewers to approach stereotypes in fiction in a similar manner.

text: Society was headed in this direction anyway, and the pandemic only helped speed up the pace of society's inevitable digital transformation. At the moment, the reason for doing that is disease prevention, but since it began, I've found that I can do just as much, or more work from home than in the office. Another example is   keeping in touch with my entire extended family and friends by text message, email, Snapchat and Instagram. Even before the pandemic, this was starting to replace the time I used to spend talking on the phone with them, so now, it's become the main way of staying in touch, but I'm convinced it was going to do that anyway. text: So, no, I do not believe in making keeping informed of current events a priority. In fact, in today's society, increasing numbers of individuals are failing to fulfill their actual responsibilities of feeding and clothing their families, paying their bills, etc.. It's entirely possible that these people who are neglecting their real responsibilities are spending more time online in social networks, and paying more attention to current events as a result. In that case, keeping engaged with 'the world' is not only not helping to make them better citizens, it is actually making them worse, ones given that they are neglecting their legitimate duties. Assuming that one *is* taking care of their actual responsibilities though, and wishes to become informed on current events, I question the feasibility of doing so. The amount of information is so vast, and it is so difficult to separate the useful information from the useless and even harmful stuff, that I'm uncertain that the average citizen could accomplish that feat even if they wanted to. Just making the effort , and taking the time, to become usefully informed on all current events could prove to be such a tremendous drain on time and resources, that having the time to fulfill one's proper duties might become problematic. The idea of the good citizen, simply being one who cares enough about society to get informed on what is going on in the world, and then being able to make informed political choices, is an appealing one. But in today's world, with contemporary technology and institutions, I suspect that the achievement of such a citizen is becoming more and more difficult.

Whether you have athletic goals, or academic goals, a goal to get a boyfriend/girlfriend, a goal to be the leader of a club, etc. As long as you are doing something productive towards your goal, there is no way you fail. If you can shift your mind to take the positive out of any negative situation, it is a sure fire way to be happy in your life and learn from your mistakes. I think teenagers and kids in general need to take their mind and mental health so much more seriously, and learn how to control their thoughts and brain before their lives get to stressful. When you become an adult, there are so many more things you need to think about. If you dont know how to talk about your emotions and deal with them by the time you get older, it can be very difficult to do things like go after your goals or be helpful to other people. You need to help yourself before you can help others, and being aware of this as early as high school is a great way to continue to grow as a human. For me personally, knowing that i can achieve whatever goal i work at has impacted my life greatly. I am addicted to pursuing goals, and if i dont have one i feel empty. I played sports all my life, so that was something that always gave me a goal to work on. However, when i finished playing football in college, i realized that i needed to start and find goals outside of athletics. To me, the main takeaway was simply to continue to take risks and improve myself. I realized that i need some sort of athletic in my life for its ability to calm my mind and body. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. text: Assuming that we don't want to get into the business of banning sports that have been around for years, I think it's reasonable to use the most dangerous existing sports, as an upper limit on what is acceptable. The question then becomes, what is the most dangerous sport? The likely answer is some kind of combat sport, like boxing, mixed martial arts, or wrestling. The athletes who compete in those sports are risking serious injury and even death, each and every time they step into the ring or onto the mat. Exactly how high the risk is, could be calculated by looking at the number of deaths and serious injuries per year, and the number of participants.
label: user_and_api

text: So, this number would be the upper limit for acceptable risk in a particular sport. It follows that when a new sport is introduced, it should be compared to this upper limit, and if it is more dangerous in terms of injuries or deaths, it should be banned. This could be tricky; for example, in boxing, the risk of death is relatively low, but the risk of brain damage is high.
label: user_and_api

text: Other dangerous sports reverse this trend. Some regulatory agency would have to be created to make these kinds of comparisons between sports, and to decide which ones are too dangerous to be allowed. Of course, a new sport might not have detailed records of injuries and deaths, so it would be necessary to estimate the risk. If deemed too high, the organization that created the sport would have to make changes to reduce the risk, or else competition in it would be prohibited. Once a sport is established, records would have to be kept of injuries and deaths, so that the risk could be calculated. A sport that exceeds the threshold, would be required to make changes to reduce the risk, or else it would be banned. This would apply to existing sports, as well as new ones. Sports are an inherently dangerous activity, and there is no way to eliminate all risk. However, it seems absurd to attempt to ban all dangerous sports, as some people have suggested, because this would begin a disturbing trend of government interference in our lives. The best approach is a rational, common-sense, empirical one, aiming to set a reasonable limit on the acceptable level of risk, and then to require that all sports stay below that level. This will balance the desire for personal liberty, with the need to protect the safety of the participants.

text: There are pros and cons to everything and dating apps and websites are no different. Many people have had success with dating apps. People meet on the app and fast forward 5-10 years and they're married. Technology has helped ease the stress and anxiety that goes into dating. I don't care who you are, there is always nerves when you're meeting someone for the first time that you're attracted to. Luckily, technology allows us to break the ice and speak to those people before meeting them in person. FaceTime allows us to confirm that the person we're talking to on the other side is real and isn't a Catfish as well. Speaking of Catfish, that is definitely a negative aspect of dating technology. There even was a television show made about it. Catfishing is simply using someone else's profile picture on a dating app to trick them into thinking they're talking to someone that they're not actually talking to. Catfishing has been used for revenge as well as in scenarios where the catfishers just have very low self esteem. Another positive aspect of technology that probably doesn't get talked about enough is the ability to catch someone cheating with evidence. This evidence can be via photograph, video or text messages. Now you might be thinking this is a negative aspect but to me, it's a positive. If you were being cheated on, would you want to know or would you rather never know and your partner is screwing you over on a daily basis and being with someone else. Sure the pain in the beginning hurts really bad but that pain is only temporary. That pain isn't as bad as being married to someone that is a cheater and doesn't truly love you. So in general, dating apps and websites and other technology have both a positive and negative affect on relationships. Since I am an optimist, I would say that the good outweighs the bad.

text: A good example is horror movies. They like to amplify characters traits because there isn't enough time for complex character development. Because of that you end up with a movie filled with stereotypes. You have the jock, the slutty one, the brain, racial stereotype and sometimes the flamboyant gay person who makes jokes. They are all written to fill a specific part of the horror movie. We're used to that formula though so I feel from a society standpoint that such roles are okay in that genre. It can be okay sometimes to have stereotypes. The characters must be at least funny or have something about them that makes them charming or likable. Then you can look past these shortcomings. If they are just flat characters then it makes it hard to be able to do that. Media has evolved when it comes to portraying stereotypes. Remakes are being done where once weak female characters are now tougher. Even the infamous Psycho death scene was changed for the show Bates Motel. The iconic female victim switched to a male victim in the shower. I personally don't have a problem with stereotypes. Sometimes I may cringe when I see them but that's part of it. Characters are getting written with more depth these days so it's becoming less of an issue.
